context: Some questions you will need to have answered include: What program of treatment is the most helpful with this diagnosis? Will this program involve services by other specialists? If so, who will be responsible for coordinating these services? What medications are generally used with this diagnosis? What is the biological effect of this medication, and what do you expect it to accomplish? What are some effects that this medication might have on my academic performance or ability to study? What are the risks associated with the medication? How soon will we be able to tell if the medication is effective, and how will we know?

context: Often, the best place to start is by talking with someone you trust about your concerns, such as a family member, friend, clergy, healthcare provider, or other professionals. Having this social support is essential in healing from mental illness, and you will be able to ask them for referrals or recommendations for trusted mental health practitioners. For more information about resources provided by UC Davis, visit the Aggie Mental Health website: https://mentalhealth.ucdavis.edu/. Secondly, there are people and places all over campus that provide services to talk, to listen, and to help you on your journey to recovery. Thirdly, many people find peer support a helpful tool that can aid in their recovery. There are a variety of organizations that offer support groups for consumers, their family members, and friends. Some support groups are peer led while others may be led by a mental health professional.

qas.question: Where else can I get help?

answers.text: Often, the best place to start is by talking with someone you trust about your concerns, such as a family member, friend, clergy, healthcare provider, or other professionals. Having this social support is essential in healing from mental illness, and you will be able to ask them for referrals or recommendations for trusted mental health practitioners. For more information about resources provided by UC Davis, visit the Aggie Mental Health website: https://mentalhealth.ucdavis.edu/

context: What is the medication supposed to do? When should it begin to take effect, and how will I know when it is effective? 3. How is the medication taken and for how long? What food, drinks, other medicines, and activities should be avoided while taking this medication? What are the side effects and what should be done if they occur? What do I do if a dose is missed? Is there any written information available about this medication? Are there other medications that might be appropriate? If so, why do you prefer the one you have chosen? How do you monitor medications and what symptoms indicate that they should be raised, lowered, or changed? All medications should be taken as directed.

context: It is not uncommon for people to stop taking their medication when they feel their symptoms are under control. Others may choose to stop taking their medication because of its side effects, without realizing that most side effects can be effectively managed. While it may seem reasonable to stop taking the medication, the problem is that most often, the symptoms will return. Another problem with stopping medication, particularly for stopping it abruptly, is that you may develop withdrawal symptoms that can be very unpleasant. If you and your doctor feel a trial off your medicine is a good idea, it is necessary to slowly decrease the dosage of medications so that these symptoms don’t occur.

qas.question: If I feel better after taking medication, does this mean I am 'cured' and can stop taking it?

answers.text: It is not uncommon for people to stop taking their medication when they feel their symptoms are under control. Others may choose to stop taking their medication because of its side effects, without realizing that most side effects can be effectively managed. While it may seem reasonable to stop taking the medication, the problem is that most often, the symptoms will return. Another problem with stopping medication, particularly for stopping it abruptly, is that you may develop withdrawal symptoms that can be very unpleasant. If you and your doctor feel a trial off your medicine is a good idea, it is necessary to slowly decrease the dosage of medications so that these symptoms don’t occur.

context: UC Ship (University of California Student Health Insurance Plan) typically provides coverage for prescription medications. However, the specifics of the coverage may vary depending on the plan and the medication. It's important to check the plan details and formulary (list of covered medications) to see what medications are covered and what costs or restrictions may apply. Additionally, some medications may require prior authorization or step therapy, which means that your doctor may need to provide additional information to the insurance company before the medication will be covered. It's always a good idea to check with the insurance company or the pharmacy to confirm coverage and any associated costs.

qas.question: How can I get help paying for my medication?

answers.text: UC Ship (University of California Student Health Insurance Plan) typically provides coverage for prescription medications. However, the specifics of the coverage may vary depending on the plan and the medication. It's important to check the plan details and formulary (list of covered medications) to see what medications are covered and what costs or restrictions may apply.

context: Student Health and Counseling Services (SHCS) offers both medical and mental health acute care services on the first floor of the Student Health & Wellness Center during normal hours of operation at 930 Orchard Rd, Davis, CA 95616 for Drop-in appointments or call (530) 752-2349. Costs for same-day appointment for mental health concerns are free.  For after-hours, call  (530) 752-2349 for Crisis Counseling Consultation. If this is an emergency, call 911 immediately. Here's more information on the Student Health and Counseling Services: https://shcs.ucdavis.edu/

context: According to the UC SHIP website, 'The University of California Student Health Insurance Plan (UC SHIP) provides high-quality, affordable and convenient coverage that protects students from unexpected health care costs. The plan is built especially for students, and students are actively involved in its design.' UC students are mandated to be under a health insurance plan, so students at UC Davis are automatically enrolled into UC SHIP and must submit a waiver with proof of alternate health insurance for the insurance coverage and associated fees to be waived.

qas.question: What is UC SHIP?

answers.text: According to the UC SHIP website, 'The University of California Student Health Insurance Plan (UC SHIP) provides high-quality, affordable and convenient coverage that protects students from unexpected health care costs. The plan is built especially for students, and students are actively involved in its design.' UC students are mandated to be under a health insurance plan, so students at UC Davis are automatically enrolled into UC SHIP and must submit a waiver with proof of alternate health insurance for the insurance coverage and associated fees to be waived.

context: If your beliefs, thoughts, feelings or behaviours have a significant impact on your ability to function in what might be considered a normal or ordinary way, it would be important to seek help. Some ways this might manifest for college students is developing an irregular sleep or eating schedule, having trouble concentrating or studying, experiencing a precipitous drop in energy levels or motivation, or feeling no desire to talk to or interact with family members and friends.

context: It may be tempting to try to block out the world altogether to avoid bad news, but it's important to keep yourself informed. It's important that you know what must be done and how you should do it. This is important for the health of your neighbors and your own mental health, and taking action can help counter difficult feelings like hopelessness and despair.

qas.question: Why do I need to keep informed?

answers.text: It's important that you know what must be done and how you should do it. This is important for the health of your neighbors and your own mental health, and taking action can help counter difficult feelings like hopelessness and despair.

context:
Anyone can post anything online. It's up to the readers to think critically about information to decide if it seems helpful, truthful, or safe. Here are key points to keep in mind as you determine which information is worth considering and which information doesn't pass the test.
It's so easy to spread information online, and we can't assume that the source we're reading or watching is the original source. Before you can evaluate anything, you need to know where the claims come from and determine if it's a reliable source.
Reliable sources on the coronavirus and COVID-19 illness include the World Health Organization (WHO), different US governement agencies including the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention(CDC), and well-known universities (including any in the UC system). Scientists and researchers at universities and other institutions and health sciences professionals are also important sources of information. 
Headlines and titles need to be simple and short, so they can sometimes be misleading on their own. They may also be purposefully shocking or controversial to entice you to click to read more. 
Websites that belong to governments, government-funded agencies, well-known health providers, universities, or groups of medical professionals are generally the most reliable. Be careful of sites that don't list the author or don't tell you much about themselves. Double-check the author and the credentials of any 'experts' quoted or cited to see if they are actually experts in the topic being discussed. 
Can you find other evidence from other sources to support the claims? Does the author list their sources? Are the sources legitimate, like research journals? 
Unhelpful sources want you to feel a certain way: scared, angry, distrustful, vulnerable. Phrases like "Skyrocketing rates of infection" are sensational and they're meant to make people feel afraid. On the other hand, factual statements like "We have 50 new cases in BC" give you important information without playing into your emotions. Helpful news or information sources want you feel informed and empowered. Who is paying for the site? What products or services are being advertised? What links or other sites do they promote? Are you learning something from a story or experience, or are you simply being directed to buy a product or service? Social media can be a great way to keep in touch with family and friends, especially as we practice physical distancing or self-isolation. Social media can also be an important way to learn from health experts and connect to support services and mutual aid groups in your community. Like any other source of information, it's important to use good critical thinking skills when you use social media. Studies find that searching for health information on social media generally has very mixed results. You'll see both very poor-quality sources next to good-quality sources, and it's up to you to decide which is which. In addition, social media posts tend to be short and rarely capture everything you need to consider. They are generally useful as a way to start learning or exploring different points of view rather than a place to gather all the information. Visit www.mediasmarts.ca to learn more about digital and media literacy. Visit www.healthnewsreview.org to learn more about thinking critically around health claims (this resource is no longer updated daily, but all toolkits and lessons are still available). This page is adapted from the Evaluating Mental Health and Substance Use Information info sheet.

qas.question: How can I tell if health information is good or bad?

answers.text:
It's up to the readers to think critically about information to decide if it seems helpful, truthful, or safe. Here are key points to keep in mind as you determine which information is worth considering and which information doesn't pass the test.
It's so easy to spread information online, and we can't assume that the source we're reading or watching is the original source. Before you can evaluate anything, you need to know where the claims come from and determine if it's a reliable source.

context:
You can foster your physical wellness by:
Finding time to move your body. Try to move your body in a way that increases your heart rate everyday for at least 30 minutes. You can even break up your daily 30 minutes into three ten-minute bouts!
Using the stairs instead of the elevator or escalator, if you’re able.
Learning to recognize warning signs when your body begins feeling ill.
Eating foods that make you feel good.
Maintaining a regular sleep schedule and get between 7-9 hours of sleep each night.
Practicing safer sex and getting yourself tested for STIs, including HIV, at least annually if you are sexually active.

qas.question: How can I take care of my physical health?

answers.text:
You can foster your physical wellness by:
Finding time to move your body. Try to move your body in a way that increases your heart rate everyday for at least 30 minutes. You can even break up your daily 30 minutes into three ten-minute bouts!
Using the stairs instead of the elevator or escalator, if you’re able.
Learning to recognize warning signs when your body begins feeling ill.
Eating foods that make you feel good.
Maintaining a regular sleep schedule and get between 7-9 hours of sleep each night.
Practicing safer sex and getting yourself tested for STIs, including HIV, at least annually if you are sexually active.

context: Distraction can help manage difficult thoughts or feelings. Examples of distraction techniques include engaging in a hobby or activity, exercising, spending time with friends or family, practicing mindfulness or meditation, and listening to music or podcasts. The goal is to shift your focus away from negative thoughts and feelings towards something positive or neutral.

qas.question: How can I use distraction to manage difficult thoughts or feelings?

answers.text: Examples of distraction techniques include engaging in a hobby or activity, exercising, spending time with friends or family, practicing mindfulness or meditation, and listening to music or podcasts. The goal is to shift your focus away from negative thoughts and feelings towards something positive or neutral.

context: If you require emergency inpatient care, you can go to the UC Davis Medical Center Emergency Department (https://health.ucdavis.edu/emergency/patients/index.html), which is located at 2315 Stockton Blvd, Sacramento, CA 95817. You can also call 911 for emergency services. If you have health insurance through UC Davis, you can check your plan to see which hospitals and providers are in your network for inpatient care. Your insurance company can provide you with a list of hospitals and providers that are covered under your plan.It's important to note that inpatient care can be expensive, so it's important to check with your insurance company and healthcare providers to understand the costs involved and any financial assistance options that may be available to you.

Your insurance company can provide you with a list of hospitals and providers that are covered under your plan.

context: Sometimes, consumers of mental health services may consider participating in a research study when they have not experienced improvement despite having tried a variety of medications and treatments. Research studies (also known as clinical trials) may involve the use of new medications or new treatment approaches whose safety and effectiveness is being tested. While we support innovation in the field, consumers should be cautioned that there are risks associated with clinical trials – make sure you’re aware of them before you enroll.

qas.question: Where can I learn more information about clinical trials?

answers.text: Sometimes, consumers of mental health services may consider participating in a research study when they have not experienced improvement despite having tried a variety of medications and treatments. Research studies (also known as clinical trials) may involve the use of new medications or new treatment approaches whose safety and effectiveness is being tested. While we support innovation in the field, consumers should be cautioned that there are risks associated with clinical trials – make sure you’re aware of them before you enroll.

context: Similar to a medical advance directive or a health care power of attorney, a psychiatric advance directive is a legal document completed in a time of wellness that provides instructions regarding treatment or services one wishes to have or not have during a mental health crisis, and may help influence his or her care. To learn more about creating a PAD in California, go to this website: https://nrc-pad.org/states/california-faq/. Keep in mind that healthcare providers may choose not to follow the PAD if you are mandated to receive treatment.

qas.question: Where can I learn more information about creating a Psychiatric Advance Directive?

answers.text: Similar to a medical advance directive or a health care power of attorney, a psychiatric advance directive is a legal document completed in a time of wellness that provides instructions regarding treatment or services one wishes to have or not have during a mental health crisis, and may help influence his or her care. To learn more about creating a PAD in California, go to this website: https://nrc-pad.org/states/california-faq/. Keep in mind that healthcare providers may choose not to follow the PAD if you are mandated to receive treatment.

context: We can all suffer from mental health challenges, but developing our wellbeing, resilience, and seeking help early can help prevent challenges becoming serious. Self care is a major part of maintaining one's wellbeing and reducing stress, with cognitive, emotional, interpersonal, physical, practical, and spiritual components.

qas.question: Can you prevent mental health problems?

answers.text: We can all suffer from mental health challenges, but developing our wellbeing, resilience, and seeking help early can help prevent challenges becoming serious. Self care is a major part of maintaining one's wellbeing and reducing stress, with cognitive, emotional, interpersonal, physical, practical, and spiritual components.

context: It is often more realistic and helpful to find out what helps with the issues you face. Talking, counselling, medication, friendships, exercise, good sleep and nutrition, and meaningful occupation can all help. Often, there is no magic bullet for a specific mental health issue, but approaching the problem with some combination of the aforementioned methods is usually effective.

qas.question: Are there cures for mental health problems?

answers.text: It is often more realistic and helpful to find out what helps with the issues you face. Talking, counselling, medication, friendships, exercise, good sleep and nutrition, and meaningful occupation can all help. Often, there is no magic bullet for a specific mental health issue, but approaching the problem with some combination of the aforementioned methods is usually effective.

context: According to the UC Davis Student Affairs website: 'At UC Davis, 1 out of 3 students reported experiencing psychological distress, according to a recent assessment by the American College Health Association. 58.1% reported experiencing loneliness, and 30.6% reporting having thoughts of suicide using the Suicide Behaviors Questionnaire- Revised (SBQR).' This proves that mental health problems are quite common at UC Davis—if you are struggling, you are definitely not alone.

context: General tips for reducing insomnia include staying off your phone and reducing screen time directly before going to bed, getting plenty of exercise, maintaining a healthy and consistent eating schedule, and writing down a to-do list for the next day. The Sleep page on the healthy UC Davis website has resources for people to deal with insomnia: https://healthy.ucdavis.edu/mental-emotional/resource-library/general/sleep.

qas.question: What are some tools to deal with insomnia?

answers.text: General tips for reducing insomnia include staying off your phone and reducing screen time directly before going to bed, getting plenty of exercise, maintaining a healthy and consistent eating schedule, and writing down a to-do list for the next day. The Sleep page on the healthy UC Davis website has resources for people to deal with insomnia: https://healthy.ucdavis.edu/mental-emotional/resource-library/general/sleep.

context: The key component to a healthy sleep schedule is consistency: ensure that classes and meetings are scheduled such that you can sleep and wake up around the same time every day, and at a time that you are comfortable with based on your sleep habits. Avoiding procrastination is also key to reducing the need to pull all-nighters to study or finish assignments. Having a consistent nightly routine also improves one's sleep schedule and reduces insomnia.

qas.question: How can I improve my sleep schedule?

answers.text: The key component to a healthy sleep schedule is consistency: ensure that classes and meetings are scheduled such that you can sleep and wake up around the same time every day, and at a time that you are comfortable with based on your sleep habits. context: Student Disability Center (SDC) accomodations can be made for mental health purposes, which will allow for extensions or extra time on assignments or exams. To request initial accomodations, it is recommended to ask early (within the first 2 weeks of a quarter) so that accomodations can be approved in time, but they may be provided if requested on short notice. The SDC website has these instructions for submitting an initial request for accomodations: https://sdc.ucdavis.edu/request.

qas.question: How can I request a mental-health based extension on an assignment or exam?
